block-definition.s: stop completing before generating any of %'stop' (AI21)
block-definition.comment: Stops decoding if any of the stop texts is generated. The decoded result text will not include the stop sequence text, but it will be included in the raw token data, which can also continue beyond the stop sequence if the sequence ended in the middle of a token.

block-definition.s: stop completing after generating any of %'stop' (Cohere)
block-definition.comment: A stop sequence will cut off your generation at the end of the sequence. Providing multiple stop sequences in the array will cut the generation at the first stop sequence in the generation, if applicable.

block-definition.s: maximum number of tokens %'max' for model named %'model'
block-definition.comment: The maximum number of tokens to generate in the completion. The token count of your prompt plus max tokens cannot exceed the model's context length. Most models have a context length of 2048 tokens. More tokens takes more time and costs more. More info at https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/parameter-details https://studio.ai21.com/docs/api/#request https://docs.cohere.ai/generate-reference#request

inputs.input: GPT-3ada babbage curie davinci j1-jumbo j1-large small medium large xlarge

block-definition.comment: High values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics. 'penality' should range from 0 to 1. More info at https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/parameter-details https://studio.ai21.com/docs/api/#repetition-penalties https://docs.cohere.ai/generate-reference#request

input.options: ada babbage curie davinci j1-jumbo j1-large small medium large xlarge

block-definition.comment: High values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim. 'penality' should range from 0 to 1. More info at https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/parameter-details https://studio.ai21.com/docs/api/#repetition-penalties https://docs.cohere.ai/generate-reference#request

input.options: ada babbage curie davinci j1-jumbo j1-large small medium large xlarge

block-definition.comment: What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. A temperature of zero will always take the most like next token (word) which is good when expecting a well-defined answer. 'temperature' should normally be between 0 and 1. But OpenAI accepts values up to 2 and others up to 5. We generally recommend altering this or top_p but not both. More info at https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/parameter-details https://studio.ai21.com/docs/api/#request https://docs.cohere.ai/generate-reference#request

block-definition.s: stop completing before generating any of %'stop'

block.comment: 4 is the maximum number of stop signals.

block-definition.comment: This block allows you to set the pen's color, transparency (on a scale from 0=opaque to 100=invisible), or size (in pixels). The color can be set in many ways, including RGB values, HSV values, HSL values, fair HSV or HSL (based on a modified spectrum that gives each spectral color equal space and promotes brown to a color), color number, crayon, or X11/W3C color name. See Appendix A in the Snap! Reference Manual for details.

input.options: color color number crayon fair hue ~1 size transparency X11/W3C name ~2 (3D color spaces)={ fair HSL={ fair hue fair saturation (HSL) fair lightness fair HSL vector } fair HSV={ fair hue fair saturation (HSV) fair value (brightness) fair HSV vector } HSL={ hue saturation (HSL) lightness HSL vector } HSV={ hue saturation (HSV) value (brightness) HSV vector } RGB (0-255)={ red green blue RGB(A) vector RGB(A) hex } }

scripts.comment: Note to myself: When the user sets a fair dimension, say fair HSL, variable HSL contains the corresponding "unfair" values, and "raw HSL" contains the numbers the user actually gave. It has to be this way because in the case of HSV, there is no "HSV" variable; rather, we use the pen's actual remembered-by-Javascript color's HSV coordinates. So our HSL variable has to be analogous to that. In both cases "raw" means the numbers the user gave us.

block-definition.comment: Sets the pen color to one of 100 preselected colors, like a box of 100 crayons. The colors have names that are meant to be evocative. They are organized in families, more or less corresponding to spectral (rainbow) colors; the input slot has a two-level menu in which you can hover over a family name to see the colors of that family, each including a crayon number and an RGB value. See Appendix A of the Snap! Reference Manual for more details.

custom-block.s: set pen color to r: %n g: %n b: %n

block-definition.s: set pen color to r: %'r' g: %'g' b: %'b'
block-definition.comment: Takes three inputs for red, green, and blue values, each between 0 and 255. 0,0,0 is black; 255,255,255 is white. 255,255,0 is yellow, and so on. The SET PEN block in this library lets you set individual red, green, or blue without changing the others, lets you provide a list of three RGB color components, and lets you provide a six-digit hexadecimal number, the form in which RGB color values are usually found online. See Appendix A of the Snap! Reference Manual for details.
block-definition.translations: pt:altera a cor da tua caneta para vermelho _ , verde _ e azul _ (0 a 255)

block-definition.s: set pen color to h: %'h' s: %'s' v: %'v'
block-definition.comment: Takes three inputs for hue, saturation, and value ("brightness") values, each between 0 and 1. 0,0,0 is black; 0,0,1 is white. 0.15,1,1 is yellow, and so on. The SET PEN block in this library lets you set individual hue, saturation, or value without changing the others, lets you provide a list of three HSV color components, and lets you use the very much superior HSL (hue, saturation, lightness) color space. See Appendix A of the Snap! Reference Manual for details.
block-definition.translations: pt:altera a cor da caneta para matiz _ , saturação _ e brilho _ (0 a 1)

block-definition.comment: Reports the current pen color as a list of three RGB values in the range 0-255. The PEN block in this library provides a large set of ways to examine the color. See Appendix A in the Snap! Reference Manual for details.
block-definition.translations: pt:a cor da caneta em RGB (vermelho, verde e azul; 0 a 255)

block-definition.comment: Reports the current pen color as a list of three HSV values in the range 0-1. See Appendix A in the Snap! Reference Manual for details.
block-definition.translations: pt:a cor da caneta em HSV (matiz, saturação e brilho, 0 a 1)

block-definition.comment: Reports the part of the first string up to the first instance of the second string inside it. If the second string isn't found, reports the entire first string.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ antes de _

custom-block.s: substring of %txt from position %n to position %n inclusive

block-definition.comment: If input is TRUE, comparisons made by functions in the string library will be case-independent (so "FOO" = "foo"). This is the default. If input is FALSE, comparisons will be exact.
block-definition.translations: pt:altera comparações ignorando distinção minúsculas/maiúsculas para _

block-definition.comment: This block creates new variables on the selected scope: global (for all sprites), sprite (for this sprite only) or script (only for that blocks stack) with the names given (in 'names' list). If there is already a variable with that name in that scope, it does nothing: no errors and no overwrites.
block-definition.translations: pt:cria as variáveis _ _ ca:crea les _ variables _ es:crear las _ variables _ de:erstellen _ var _

block-definition.comment: This block reports "true" if there is a variable with this given name (input slot) in that context. It can be a global, sprite or script variable. Otherwise it reports "false".
block-definition.translations: pt:a variável _ existe ca:existeix la variable _ ? es:existe la variable _ ? de:existiert var _ ?

input.options: ada babbage curie davinci j1-jumbo j1-largesmall medium large xlarge command-xlarge-20221108

block-definition.comment: Reports True if the first input string contains the second input string, otherwise false. Comparison is case-independent by default; use USE CASE-INDEPENDENT COMPARISONS to change that.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ antes de _ ca:text _ conté _ ?

block-definition.comment: Reports the character position (starting from 1) of the beginning of the first input string inside the second input string. If it's not found, reports 0.
block-definition.translations: pt:a posição de _ em _ ca:posició de _ en _
ca:comparacions ignorant majúscules?

block-definition.comment: Reports the input text with lower case letters instead of capital letters in the input. Uses the user's locale's rules for case conversion.
block-definition.translations: pt:em minúsculas _ ca:_ a minúscules

block-definition.s: substring of %'str' from position %'start' to position %'end' inclusive
block-definition.comment: Reports the portion of the first input (string) starting at the position given by the second input (counting from 1, like LETTER n OF) and ending at the position given by the third input (also counting from 1). If the third input is empty, reports the portion from the first position to the end of the string. If a position number is negative, counts from the end backward, so -1 is the last character, -2 is the next to last, etc.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ entre as posições _ e _ , inclusive

block-definition.comment: No longer needed in Snap! 7+ but retained to avoid error from blocks that expect it.

scripts.comment: Click this to read about this project

variable.name: topic
variable.l: It is OK for people to wear transparent clothing

variable.name: getting first arguments
variable.l: The first team began by presenting the following arguments:

variable.name: elicting counter arguments
variable.l: One team made the following arguments: 1. There is a potential for artificial intelligence to be used for harm. 2. We don't fully understand artificial intelligence and its implications. 3. Slowing down research will allow us to better understand artificial intelligence and how to control it. The competing team responded:

variable.name: debate
variable.l: Initial arguments for topic: It is OK for people to wear transparent clothing The affirmative team: 1. Freedom of expression: People should be allowed to express themselves through their clothing choices, including wearing transparent clothing. 2. Comfort: Transparent clothing can be more comfortable in hot weather or during physical activity. 3. Fashion: Transparent clothing is a popular trend in fashion and should not be restricted. 4. Body positivity: Wearing transparent clothing can promote body positivity and self-confidence. ======================= The negative team: 1. Transparent clothing can be indecent and offensive to some people, especially in public places where children and families are present. 2. Wearing transparent clothing can lead to objectification and sexualization of the wearer, which perpetuates harmful societal norms and stereotypes. 3. Transparent clothing can also create discomfort and distraction in professional settings, such as in the workplace or in educational institutions. 4. The freedom to wear transparent clothing should not override the responsibility to respect the cultural and social norms of the community. ======================= Refutations: The affirmative team: 1. The negative team assumes that everyone finds transparent clothing indecent and offensive, which is not necessarily true. People have different opinions and preferences when it comes to fashion and clothing. Moreover, it is not fair to restrict someone's freedom to express themselves through their clothing based on the sensitivities of a few individuals. 2. The negative team is making a sweeping generalization about the effects of wearing transparent clothing. While it is true that objectification and sexualization can occur, it is not always the case. People should have the agency to wear what they want without being judged or stereotyped based on their clothing choices. 3. The negative team is assuming that transparent clothing is always inappropriate in professional settings. However, there are ways to wear transparent clothing in a tasteful and professional manner, such as layering or pairing it with more conservative pieces. It is up to the individual to decide what is appropriate for their workplace or educational institution. 4. The negative team is suggesting that cultural and ======================= The negative team: 1. Freedom of expression: While freedom of expression is an important value, it is not an absolute right. Society also has a responsibility to protect public decency and morality. Wearing transparent clothing can be inappropriate in certain settings, such as schools, workplaces, or religious institutions, where it may offend others or distract from the purpose of the setting. 2. Comfort: While transparent clothing may be more comfortable in some situations, such as at the beach or in a gym, it is not appropriate for all occasions. It is important to consider the context and dress appropriately for the occasion. 3. Fashion: While fashion is constantly evolving, it is not always appropriate or acceptable. Transparent clothing may be a trend, but it can also be seen as inappropriate or indecent in certain settings. 4. Body positivity: While promoting body positivity is important, it should not be done at the expense of public decency or morality. Wearing transparent clothing can be seen as inappropriate or indecent and may offend others. ======================= Additional arguments: The affirmative team: 5. Consent: Wearing transparent clothing is a personal choice and should only be done with the consent of the wearer. If someone feels comfortable and confident wearing transparent clothing, they should be allowed to do so without judgment or criticism. 6. Gender equality: Women have been traditionally restricted in their clothing choices and have been shamed for wearing revealing clothing. Allowing transparent clothing promotes gender equality and breaks down traditional gender norms. 7. Cultural significance: Transparent clothing has cultural significance in some parts of the world and should not be dismissed as inappropriate or offensive. 8. Personal responsibility: It is the responsibility of the individual to choose what they wear and how they present themselves to the world. As long as they are not harming anyone else, they should be ======================= The negative team: 5. Transparent clothing can also be a safety hazard, as it can distract drivers and cause accidents on the road. 6. Wearing transparent clothing can also lead to unwanted attention and harassment, which can make the wearer feel uncomfortable and unsafe. 7. The promotion of transparent clothing as acceptable can also contribute to the objectification and sexualization of women, which can have negative effects on their mental and emotional well-being. 8. Allowing transparent clothing can also lead to a slippery slope where other forms of inappropriate clothing may be deemed acceptable, further eroding societal norms and values. ======================= The affirmative team summary: The affirmative team argues that people should be allowed to wear transparent clothing for reasons such as freedom of expression, comfort, fashion, body positivity, consent, gender equality, cultural significance, and personal responsibility. They refute the negative team's arguments that transparent clothing is always indecent and offensive, that it leads to objectification and sexualization, that it is always inappropriate in professional settings, and that it goes against cultural and moral values. The affirmative team believes that people should have the agency to choose what they wear without being judged or restricted. ======================= The negative team summary: The negative team argues that wearing transparent clothing can be indecent, offensive, and distracting in certain settings, such as public places, workplaces, and educational institutions. It can also lead to objectification, sexualization, and harassment of the wearer. The promotion of transparent clothing as acceptable can contribute to the erosion of societal norms and values. While freedom of expression, comfort, fashion, and body positivity are important values, they should not override the responsibility to respect public decency and morality. =======================
